page.title: 10CHESTERTON MILL
page.content: Five miles South_East Leamington Spa on a hill above the Fosseway.Open six arched base built from stone possibly from old Chesterton Manor.The original wooden upper storey,replaced by brick in the 19th century,with domed lead roof and sails of the common type. Building erected 1632 for Sir Edward Payto or Son Edward,possibly as an observatory.However a 1649 marriage settlement refers to the building as a mill for grinding corn.Many years ago the miller who owned both Chesterton and Harbury mills would set the sails at Harbury then ride to Chesterton to work that mill,at the same time watched for a change in the weather.At Chesterton he sails there,then on a fast horse gallop to Harbury in time to adjust the sails there.
